good for those of you who are not familiar with them I will now try to explain how and also why they work and
we need to start with the simplest part what is an image so this is what we see
when we see an image but the computer sees just the matrix with pixel values
and since this is a grayscale image it's one matrix if it was a colored image it would be three are red green
blue so RGB image and what the convolutional neural networks does is
that they use a process called convolution so you have an input image
this is just a very simple example of what an input image could be and then you have something called filters and
the filters are there to recognize specific features in an image and which
feature that filter can recognize depends on what values you have in the filter and a typical feature could be a
specific color a straight line a curve or diagonal and so on so it's very
simple features but what you do is that you take this filter and you slide it
across the input image producing dot products so you multiplied the pixel value with the filter value and you save
the results into what is called an activation map and what the activation
value tells you is to what degree does that part of the image contain the
specific feature that that filter can recognize so if the filter can recognize
the color yellow and you get a high value in the activation map it means that that part of the image is red so
you continue on you slide the filter across the image and you learn to what
degree the feature exists in every part but you do this not just with one filter
you do this with several filters all producing different activation maps and different representation of that image
so you learn where in the image is does it contain the color red the color
yellow edges curves and so on and then you continue on you take new filters and
you process them over the activation maps allowing you to not only recognize these simple features but also
combination combinations of them so combination of the color red and a curve
combination of the color red a curve and yellow and so on so the further incident
Network you get the more complex features you're able to recognize so with a car for example it
starts out with these simple edges and colors and it becomes more more and more
specific to a car you can see that it's kind of wheels and the lower part of a window and so on and then finally you
can see that it's actually cars another
important part of these convolutional neural networks is the pooling layer and the pooling layers are used to down
sample the size of an image and you do this to reduce to get a reduction of
dimensions to reduce the amount of parameters that you have to calculate because there's so much to calculate so
we kind of need to reduce it somehow but you also do it to get rotation and
positional invariance which means that you're generalizing what the image
contains you're kind of taking away some information and just saving the most important part and so it won't matter
that much if the image has some difference in color if it's rotated a
little bit or if it's cropped and pooling layer is often done with the max
pooling operation where you just save the highest value in sub parts of the image so that's how you down sample it
but you also need to be able to upscale the image again because we don't want to lose resolution and upscaling is done by
a process called transposed convolution where you have filters that learn how to
upscale the images again and it's not that important to know exactly how this
is done but you should know that there is a technique to to upscale the images again so the architecture usually looks
something like this where you have all the layers stacked after each other the convolutional layers where the filters
are and then the pooling layers to down sample and then the up sampling layers again but we need to train these
networks and what exactly does it mean to train a network basically what you do is that you give
the network a lot of examples of what you wanted to learn with known known output so you make the network figure
out how to map given input with given output so if you want to network to
learn to classify cats you need to give it a lot of examples of images of cats
and not just these images but a lot more and you also need to give it images that
it's not cats but similar to cats like dogs and so on and what the network does
is that it tries to figure out what values can you put in the filters to
find filters that recognizes features that are in all images of cats
so it just tests different values in the different filters to see what values it
can put to find the features that exist so it's all just like testing and once
it finds features or filters that can recognize correct features it improves
in accuracy so it becomes better and better the more it's it's testing but
it's very important that you make sure that your model is generalizing instead of memorizing your data and what I mean
by that is that you need to make sure that your model is not just remembering
and learning the exact examples that you're giving it but that it's actually giving you a generalized model so when
usually when you start training you have this case of underfitting your model hasn't really fitted to your
data yet and if you keep on training and your chain training correctly you will
find the generalization that you're looking for that fits your data pretty
well but then if you keep on training you will have what it's called
overfitting which is where the network or the model starts memorizing your data
so it starts fitting to the specific examples that you are giving it so well that it loses its generalization and
becomes useless and the way you avoid this is by
splitting your data set into different sets so you have the training data set which is what the model uses for finding
the filters but in between training you have a validation data sets so you test
your model to see how it's performing on a different part of your data set so
what you're looking for is the point where um your model is getting better
and better at classifying samples in your training data set and it's also
getting better and better at the validation data set but at some point the validation accuracy is going to start decreasing but the training
accuracy is going to keep increasing and this is the point where it starts to memorize the data instead of
generalizing so it's very important to make sure it's not to be aware of this
specific point and then last you have the test data set that you can use to
actually check the performance of your data or of your model another thing is
to make sure that your data set is actually giving you a realistic sense of
the real world so if you're training on for example these images of cats that

convolutional neural network and then you classify that small patch and you
give that class to the center pixel and then you continue doing this for every
every pixel in the image giving you a per pixel classification so you extract
small patch send it through a CNN and gives the class to the center pixel so
when you have a fully trained network you can send in an input image and it will give you a segmented output image
